awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Foundation of Flexible and Soft Manufacturing Robot Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Advanced manufacturing robot technologies, such as soft robots, are necessary in order to increase productivity, ensure safety, and perform difficult precision tasks in many industry sectors including automotive, aerospace, food, construction, and agricultural. The control and stability of flexible and soft manufacturing robotic systems, which have complex geometries and experience desirable and undesirable deformations, are of major concern, particularly when lightweight softer materials are used. However, the mathematical foundation of such flexible and soft robots has not been established and our knowledge of their mechanics remains remarkably incomplete. The seriousness of this challenge is evident by the lack of advanced virtual prototyping techniques that are integral part of the design, analysis, and performance evaluation of other physics and engineering systems. This project will conduct fundamental research to create the mathematical foundation and new computational algorithms for flexible and soft manufacturing robot systems in order to address virtual prototyping challenges. The new mathematical foundation will improve the analysis and performance evaluation methods, capture significant details that cannot be captured by existing simplified approaches, allow for virtually testing new and improved designs, make such systems more affordable and safer, and accelerate the design, development, and commercialization of such machines. The new knowledge, approaches, and numerical algorithms developed in this research will be used in the education of undergraduate and graduate students at University of Illinois at Chicago. The broader impact will be realized through dissemination, training, and outreach activities.

The scientific challenges include the integration of the robot geometry and analysis; implementation of general and unconventional material models and actuation forces; use of new concepts for mechanical joint modelling; and developing efficient and robust algorithms for virtual prototyping. This research seeks to address these challenges by developing a new transformative continuum-based finite element and multibody system approach based on the absolute nodal coordinate formulation. This formulation allows modeling arbitrarily large and coupled displacements, correctly captures complex geometries, and allows implementing general and nonconventional material models. In this research project, accurate definitions of conventional and non-conventional actuation forces will be developed taking into consideration the complexity of the geometry of the robot components, which can be systematically captured using the finite elements of the absolute nodal coordinate formulation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Advancing manufacturing robot technology is necessary  to increase productivity, ensure safety, and perform difficult precision manufacturing tasks in many industry sectors. Control and stability of  technologically and economically important flexible and soft manufacturing robotic systems (FSMRS), which have complex geometry, are of major concern, particularly when lightweight softer materials are used. Nonetheless, the FSMRS mathematical foundation has not been established and our knowledge of the FSMRS mechanics remains remarkably incomplete. Without establishing the mathematical foundation and developing efficient computational framework, further advances in the area of manufacturing machines cannot be made. 

      The overall objective of this research is to develop the FSMRS mathematical foundation and new computational algorithms to address the FSMRS fundamental virtual prototyping challenges, which include: (1) integration of robot geometry and analysis; (2) implementation of general and unconventional material models and actuation forces; (3) use of new concepts for modelling FSMRS joints; and (4) Developing efficient and robust algorithms for FSMRS virtual prototyping. These challenges are addressed by developing new continuum-based FE and multibody system (MBS) approach that allows modeling arbitrarily large and coupled displacements, correctly captures complex geometries, allows implementing general and nonconventional material models, provides accurate definitions of conventional and non-conventional actuation forces, leads to a constant inertia matrix that defines optimally sparse matrix structure of the dynamic equations, and allows exploiting new geometry concepts to define linear and more general joint constraints instead of the less general and nonlinear joint constraints currently used for robot systems.

      Research in this area has a broader impact since manufacturing robot technology is critical to the global economic competitiveness. More reliance on flexible and soft robotic systems in future manufacturing applications in automotive, aerospace, food, and construction and agricultural machine industries will have broad significant economic, technological, and safety impact. This research, which will be based on unified geometry/analysis computational framework to influence significantly virtual product development (VPD), is the first step in developing  FSMRS virtual prototyping technology that captures significant model details. The specific outcomes of this project are summarized as follows:

  1. Evaluation of Existing FSMRS Approaches.   The concerns associated with existing simplified and FE approaches in modeling soft robots and materials are discussed to have scientific evaluation of these methods when used in the FSMRS analysis and design. This evaluation is necessary to provide justifications for using the absolute nodal coordinate formulation (ANCF) for modeling soft robot systems. To this end, existing FSMRS formulations are examined and their limitations are identified. The problems associated with preserving the geometry when other approaches are used are explained and documented to provide strong justification for using the approach adopted in this project.
  2. Development of Mathematical Foundation.  One of the main goals of this research is to establish the FSMRS mathematical foundation and define the robot inertia and elastic forces using an approach that allows arbitrarily large reference displacements and deformations. The inertia forces are formulated in terms of a constant mass matrix regardless of the amount of rotation or deformation within the element, while general continuum-mechanics approach is used to formulate nonlinear elastic forces. Using ANCF position gradients allows for accurately describing arbitrary geometry and ensures continuity of the rotation, strain, and stress fields.
  3. Integration of Geometry and Analysis.          The approach used in this research project allows for developing a single geometry/analysis mesh using ANCF elements to avoid geometry distortion resulting from converting solid models to analysis meshes. ANCF gradients allow for local shape manipulations, and adjusting distances and dimensions. An ANCF computational geometry algorithm is developed and generalized to study wide range of applications. 
  4. Definition of Actuation Forces.     Conventional actuation forces can be produced by actuators and motors, while nonconventional soft robot forces can be produced by fluid, pressurized air, and muscle-like actuation. In this project accurate definitions of the actuation forces associated with generalized coordinates are developed. The relationship between Cartesian forces and moments and the generalized forces are established and accurate definition of torsional strains in terms of ANCF position gradients is provided. Specified motion trajectories are applied, and  forces that produce desired motion are predicted using new force formulations.
  5. Development of Computational Framework.  A new computational framework that exploits new geometry and mechanics concepts and serves to reduce reliance on physical prototyping is developed to eliminate the need for using different and incompatible algorithms (CAD, FE, robotics, and MBS). ANCF Cholesky coordinates are used to obtain an identity generalized inertia matrix to allows efficient solution for the accelerations and constraint forces.
  6. Development of New Models.        New virtual prototyping algorithms  is demonstrated using FSMRS models with significant details to demonstrate implementation of the new actuation force formulations and general material models. Benchmark problems are developed to compare and contrast existing and proposed methods and. demonstrate advantages of the proposed approach using quantitative metrics in terms of computational efficiency, improvement in accuracy, and ease of analysis.
